title: Dear Coleen: My daughter has told me she doesn't want 'my kind of childcare'
text:

Dear Coleen

I’m a grandmother and I used to look after my daughter’s two children a few afternoons a week until recently, which I really enjoyed.

However, she’s decided she doesn’t want “my kind of childcare” any more, which was said in a kind of jokey way. She’s now employed a professional childminder to take care of them after school while she’s at work.

I’m quite hurt by all of this and fail to see what I’ve done that’s so terrible. I admit I’m quite relaxed when it comes to grand-parenting – I allow them treats and let them watch a bit of telly when we get back from school, but it seems this doesn’t fit in with what my daughter wants.

She claims her son has been saying inappropriate things at school, and his teacher has pulled

her up on it. She seems convinced it’s my fault for letting him watch certain TV shows. What should I do? I absolutely loved looking after them and feel quite angry she’s reacted like this.

On the other hand, I don’t want to fall out with her. Any advice?

Coleen says

Try not to take it personally and fall out with your daughter. She’s not banned you from seeing your grandchildren or from babysitting at other times. I know you liked looking after the kids but, actually, this might be best for your relationship with your daughter.

If there are things you do that she doesn’t like, it’s really hard to complain to your own mother. However, if she’s paying a childminder and doesn’t agree with something, it’s a lot easier to deal with.

If she has professional childcare then she doesn’t risk falling out with you and that’s probably a big part of her decision.

My mother-in-law used to help me with childcare, but she did things I didn’t like and it was really hard to tell her.

I would just explain to your daughter it makes sense because now you can just be their granny and you’re up for babysitting.

You have to respect how other people want to bring up their kids, but I’m sure treats can still be on the agenda in the future.
description: I enjoyed looking after the grandkids and can't see what I've done that's so terrible
